>>178219572
The last few episodes have been fine IMO.

In general though, I think part of the problem is that they're not editing the videos for content as tightly. Back in the day the episodes were ~30-45 minutes, then they were ~1 hr for the longest time, and now they regularly run up to ~1.5 hours. If we assume that the discussion takes about as long to film as it ever did (which must be the case, given their previous comments about how long the BOTW days already were), then they're filling the episodes with ~+30 minutes of content that might have otherwise been left on the chopping room floor. I enjoy the show, so I don't want to complain about getting more content ... but some of the episodes (especially the Wheel/Black Spine episodes) have started to feel like they're dragging on a bit.

Speaking of the Wheel/Black Spine episodes, it also feels like they're a bit over-engineered these days. The old Wheel episodes were fun because the videos were so random and silly, and they had to make do with what they got. Episodes were shorter, so it didn't really matter if they didn't have too much to say. And if the selected video was properly shit, they could just spin/select a new one, or play a ringer tape. So many of those older episodes felt unique because of how much randomness the format allowed. The newer "watch chunks of 50 fucking tapes" format is probably more consistent, but it also feels so much more samey than the older episodes. I don't want to sound too negative about it - I'm sure this is largely a personal taste issue, and I'm still enjoying these episodes just fine.

>>178241399
People act like heights are such a profound unconquerable fear.
It's just not true for all but a small percentage. You just need exposure, which you may have no reason to get in your day-to-day
Think about your life. For instance, in a car, you're hurtling down a rock approaching 100mph, and the barest twitch of an arm or a foot from you or any of the people around you can send you hurtling to a fiery death. A person born a few hundred years ago would tell you you're insane. You've likely driven many times without your seatbelt on just because. But it's just whatever because you do it every day.

It's the same thing with heights. I got freaked out just going to my office when I worked downtown. Exposure began to break down the initial novelty, then it finally clicked and I was like "oh the dudes who built this thing did it... while probably thinking about what was for lunch." Now I can do w/e.

The Navy was complicated. There were glass ceilings that had be broken. The great Captain James Cook was of common stock, and it was exceedingly difficult for him to achieve his rank despite how ahead of his time he was.
But it was far more meritocratic. Couldn't let any clown aristocrat be commissioned due to the complexity of running a ship of war.
Britain's national security was on the line as well, though I suspect the Duke of Wellington felt a desire for the British Army to have the same treatment given what he said of his officers at Waterloo.

https://www.bbc.com/mediacentre/mediapacks/frozen-planet-2
>Wave-washing’ involves multiple individuals swimming in tandem and then coordinating their tail beats to create waves which then go on to wash seals off ice floes. Family groups are led by matriarchs who can live to be over hundred years old. Only about 100 killer whales in the Antarctic peninsula use this complex hunting technique.

>The only other time that the wave-washing killer whales have been filmed creating waves to knock prey off ice floes was when the BBC made the original Frozen Planet series.

>For the first time Frozen Planet II films this incredible behaviour using drones from an aerial perspective, allowing the team to see how the whales coordinated their attack from the air.

posts.name: Anonymous

>Lightweight drones allowed a new angle on their amazing co-ordinated hunting. Viewed from the air, the way they form waves becomes more apparent producing new insights for science as well as television.
>The team also employed new pole cameras to give an underwater insight, where diving would have been too dangerous.
>Drones have played a big role. ‘Wave-washing’ behaviour was actually captured in the original Frozen Planet but without that aerial perspective. This is about as remote as you can be in the Antarctic Peninsula: it would be hard to get a helicopter out there and a helicopter could disturb their behaviour. I posit that TOS doesn't land well with the depression and ennui crowd because it requires a baseline of optimism and motivation to immerse oneself into a frontier exploration show. You've got to have itchy wanderlust to want to go westward to the galactic barrier.
TNG has thst but tempered with the navel gazing the depression and ennui crowd are accustomed to, in Picard's words from The Wounded,
>like old leather.
DSN9NE even more so.
Shows about exploration first hinge upon the viewer wanting to insert oneself in that world. Even Voyager had the exploration second to the concept of escape or return. Voyager is the Odyssey. DSIX is the Iliad. TNG is, I dunno, the Mahabharata or Shahnameh. But TOS is a uniquely American epic, Davy Crockett, and you gotta be pumped up on socioeconomic dominance and a desire to see what's next to enjoy it.

>>178229273
I don't dislike DS9 in and of itself - as a stand-alone show it's really good - but I feel that it's so completely removed and distant from the spirit of what made Trek good in the first place, and which shows like TOS and TNG reflect, that it's hard for me to enjoy it all that much, or feel any desire to rewatch it. As well as starting almost every single bad trend that would go on to bring down Trek in the future (dark tone, serialised stories, constant political messaging, soap opera dialogue, too much war), it just feels.... unnecessary. I don't need to be told that things like war and oppression exist and can make things miserable - I can just take one quick look at world news to see this, every single day. Just transposing all the problems of the modern world onto a sci-fi show doesn't make it intelligent or thought-provoking, it just makes it yet another reflection of grim reality, which is specifically what I DON'T watch Trek for.
The only DS9 episodes I really enjoy and feel like rewatching are Ferengi episodes, and the TOS homage episode, because they actually capture the non-pretentious, lighthearted, humorous fun of old Trek.

>>178230147
That's the dilemma that Trek writers face occasionally - making a society very in touch with their traditions and identity (e.g., Bajorans) and depicting that as positive (muh noble savages and that) but then running into the problem of having to logically follow through with that and showing them as being intolerant of outsiders coming into their culture, which conflicts with Trek's primary message of unrelenting globalism.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>178229845
>. As well as starting almost every single bad trend that would go on to bring down Trek in the future (dark tone, serialised stories, constant political messaging, soap opera dialogue, too much war), it just feels.... unnecessary.
At the risk of sounding like a certain personality, I think this was inevitable because our society is running out of frontiers to explore and growth to sustain, and the grimdark turn in trek is inseparable from the slow quiet strangulation of the American dream. We're at the point where the most promising future many dreaming is dying on a one way trip to an unterraformable dust ball to assuage the ego of a narcissistic man-child who won the societal game of Tongo. Uh, sweet.
As to your point regarding the Ferengi eps, I still maintain the Ferengi eps are DS9s own series within a series, similar to stitching together McBain clips in the Simpsons and getting a movie. It's basically their MASH.
Ignatius Cavitation was a great Vorta but can we agree that David Bowie would be an amazing cold, detached, Cardassian Gul?

TNG also did it with the Klingons - there's a clear storyline that occurs between seasons 3 and 7 dealing with all their political and societal problems that is always going on in the background and only occasionally the Enterprise crosses over to get updated on what's going on. It makes the world feel larger without having to constantly show what's happening each episode (which modern serialised series' do).
I'm tempted to download DS9 and edit together every Ferengi episode so it's an entirely stand-alone miniseries. Would be a super comfy watch.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As someone that feels like the writers made Picard too "soft" and easy-going in the later seasons of TNG, I like how they have him a tougher edge in Preemptive Strike - when Ro tells him she feels sympathy for the Maquis and isn't sure if she wants to betray them, instead of Picard being understanding, he straight up just goes "complete your mission or I'll court martial you as a traitor, woman". I like when the cold, strict military captain side of Picard comes out.
Also the final scene is possibly my favourite ending in the entire 176 episode series - a single shot as Riker tells Picard that Ro betrayed them and deserted to the Maquis, waiting for a response, but Picard sits there silently, unmoving, so Riker leaves, and the camera slowly pans in on Picard's face, expression cold as ice, leaving you to wonder if he's feeling incredible anger, disappointment, or regret. Absolutely fantastic scene, and an unusually downbeat, cold and "real" ending for TNG, especially considering it's the final "proper" episode before the finale.

>>178232556

Wells' accounting assistant is one of three characters who are almost certainly (and pretty obviously) killed by Anton. But for each of the three characters, taking the film by itself and ignorning we book, we do not have absolute proof for any of them. I'm talking about the overnight clerk at the second (Del Rio?) motel, "Accounting", this guy, and of course Carla Jean.

1) For the Del Rio clerk, we can hear the soft THUNK noise of Anton's shotgun suppressor, a moment before he stands in front of Llewelyn's second-floor room. As Llewelyn escapes, he sees a glimpse of the clerk's shoe or something, motionless. In the end, the other sherrif tells Ed Tom that the man was "shot", but without confirming the kill in his language. All signs point to the clerk being dead, but there's a slight gap on this one.

2) Accounting was probably killed. He literally sees Anton, even gets a good look at his face, and they both know it. Anton wants to be careful not to leave traces (hence fucking with the gas station clerk, which ironically leaves even more of a trace of himself). Also Anton is pissed with this drug company and has some emotional reason to take out more of their people, like he took out the other two guys at the initial crime scene. But again, it's not certain.

3) Then Carla Jean. All signs point to her being killed, yes (Anton following up his promise, checking his shoes), but it wasn't shown on screen. This is enough to give a slight ambiguity, "we don't know for certain", but the most obvious inference is that she is killed like the others.

If you're an otherwise-uninvolved clerk and you get Anton, you might live or die depending on the timing and circumstances. If you are directly involved in his "mission" (as both accounting and Carla Jean are), you can pretty much count on being fucked.

I think the gas station attendant being let go was a flaw but the purpose of that was poetic in demonstrating that Anton was something of a force of nature.

I think the accountant survives because he has a reason to be spared - this is a firm that hires mercenaries and will continue to hire mercenaries in the future. The accountant will attest that Anton was a "professional" to his superiors who hire mercenaries and if he's in the game he will keep mum about it to the police because that's how it is in the business. Anton ultimately wants repeat business and having a reputation of being square matters in his line of work. Everyone in the business will understand why Anton killed the man who hired him because the contract was meant to be exclusive to Anton. (Stephen Root) didn't uphold their half of the deal and so Anton could kill them. When you hire multiple mercenaries acting independently to do the same job, you put both of them in danger of killing each other and that's unnecessary risk. It's a risk Carson was stupid enough to take and Anton is smart enough to not tolerate.

Carla Jean was given the same 50/50 chance as the gas station guy. The accountant was given an actual choice, a choice that is given to professionals. Carson had a choice to not take the job and was killed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Anton only views himself as a force of nature, but the movie itself makes it clear that he is just a man like every one else and that one day he to will be an old man who can't keep up with the brutality and ruthlessness of modern crime.

Basically the point is that Anton is delusional, and sees himself as unstoppable. This ends up literally hitting him at the end, when a car slams into him, and he "needs a minute" to catch his breathe. He needs to rest, He's aging, becoming slower.

The sheriff just accepts that he's aging and gets out of the game.

Did Anton kill Accounting and Carla? The answer is that it doesn't matter, they are props.
This movie is dramatic because it's a crime drama, but it's the most obvious and non-subtle representation of the most overdone concept in all of art, the inability for older generations to keep up with new. Not just in crime but all aspects of life.

Anton's "rules" or "tism" or whatever you want to call it, are not consistent, it's actually arbitrary. Sometimes he lets people live without flipping a coin at all, Sometimes he kills people without flipping the coin. He is a mentally ill man with delusions of grandeur and psychosis probably.

Whatever accounting said in response to Anton, is just as likely as anything else he could have said to result in his death or being spared. You can endlessly justify any phrase as being against the rules, because the rules are nonsense.

posts.com:
First season is actually really funny, the fish-out-of-water comedy works well and it has this whole immigration satire thing going. Little Stevie's charisma carries the whole thing but the supporting cast do their bit. It's probably funnier if you actually are Norwegian. Really should have ended there, so if you're keen just watch S1.

Second season has some good moments, but the storylines start to go weird and pointless places. The basic plotline of the Mob tracking him down is pretty cool but the whole thing does feel like a rehash.

Third season was really bad, it had gone into full-blown absurdism and spent a lot of time on pointless characters. Which is a shame because the actors were great, the jokes just sucked. It ends on a cliffhanger which is funny, because it'll never be resolved.

It was the first series to be funded and produced by Netflix, and its initial success encouraged them to make more, now here we are.

>>178234478
When something is in the works or is happening, you can say that is “in the pipeline.” This idiomatic expression is especially apt for things that have to follow a set procedure and have to go through several rigorous steps to be completed.

For example, if you’ve applied for membership at a specific club and want to know the status of your application, an employee there might notify you that your application is “in the pipeline.”

The idea here is that just as pipelines transfer materials from point A to point B and do so along a well-defined path, the application that is “in the pipeline” is heading towards a path of acceptance or rejection and is doing so by following well-defined steps.

Even though the expression first appeared within the petroleum industry, which sort of makes sense, you’ll find “in the pipeline” today used as business jargon a lot.

For instance, a company official might announce that they are unable to take any more orders at this time because their pipeline is filled.

“In the pipe” is just an abbreviated form of “in the pipeline.”

In fact, “in the pipe” is used in the navy. It was used to signal that an enemy vehicle was clear ahead and that it was possible to attack said vehicle.

For example, an aviator who was aimed correctly to bomb their target would say that they were “in the pipe.”

“Five by five” is actually military jargon. You see, when it comes to radio communication, there are two main scales to gauge the quality of the transmission.

On the one hand, you have transmission clarity. On the other hand, you have transmission strength.

>>178235271

In Aliens, there are 16 characters (directly involved in the mission), the same number as the starting number of pieces for one side in chess. If I had designed the Aliens luxury chess set, I would lay out White's side as follows:

King: Newt (the most important piece, the whole objective of the game/mission, the one piece that must be protected at all costs. She can crawl easily from place to place, adjacent squares.)
Queen: Ripley. Emerges as the most powerful piece of the group as the game/movie develops.
Bishops: Bishop (of course) and Gorman. Displaying both the pros and cons of the piece type. Capable of moving in a straight line (bishop crawls a straight line of pipe for several hundred feet, an important move in the movie's game).
Knights: Drake and Vasquez. Useful point-tactical pieces.
Rooks: Apone (as the rook starting on a1), and Hicks (as the rook starting on h1). The actual powerful, capable soldiers.

This leaves us with a group of rank-and-file pawns, and we can approximate an amusing alliteration:

a-pawn: Wierzbowski: a barely-seen guy hangs out on one side.
b-pawn: Burke. Just kinda hangs out, off to the side.
c-pawn: Crowe, Often, one of the first to be captured in a game.
d-pawn: Dietrich, see above.
e-pawn: Frost, see above. Close to the f-pawn.
f-pawn: Ferro, see above.
g-pawn: Spunkmeyer, see above. These two might occupy the section of the board leading to fool's mate.
h-pawn: Hudson (fitting that this coward should occupy a weak position at the edge of the board!)

For Black's side there are roughly six "types" of fighters, so Queen = Queen, pawn = egg, knight=facehugger, bishop=chestburster, rook=adult. You might do that "sodier/drone" thing to resolve the king, this bit is tricky.

I do still have a bin filled with my GI Joes, most of which she bought me.

>>178236423
I think this actually illustrates the main flaw of the movie, which is that a lot of Bell’s context/motivation was lost in translation from the book.

After this passage in the book, Bell drives to a bridge to contemplate things while he watches the sunset. Here, he basically finds the drive he needs to continue doing his job after being reminded of his own mortality with the bodies in the trailer.

My take is that the bodies in the trailer reminded him of his “cowardice” during WW2 - the men he supposedly let die. His trip to the bridge was to find the strength needed to atone for that cowardice. Facing Anton, to him, would make up for not facing the enemy when he had lives counting on him.

Japanese is so phonetic and well pronounced that you can pick out words and phrases, and most importantly, you can repeat them back almost completely accurately. You hear a phrase in anime and you can repeat the line, and be understand by any normal Japanese person. With Chinese and other languages, it's like not only do you need to know the word but you have to change your entire mouth and facial structure to ever hope to pronounce it correctly. Russian is like that too.

Meanwhile I can "ooki oppai ga suki da" without really changing my inflection at all. That makes the language so much more tolerable. Like even listening to Hirohito's message, if you're able to find a clear enough version, it's not all that indecipherable even with his ancient phrasing. And that's a wild thought, that a message modern Japs could barely understand is still somewhat understandable. It and Spanish (sans accents) must be the easiest languages to speak.

>>178238466
Like Japanese has lots of homonyms too, like kami meaning hair, paper, or god, but you need context clues or the kanji. But generally you'll understand.

If you say Akechi Mitsuhide without any accent or inflection, you'll still stay it right. But if you say Lu Bu you'll be told it's wrong and probably pronounced more like Lee Boo. So then why the fuck is it spelled Lu Bu? Japanese doesn't have these contractions. It's phonetic, what's written is how you say it, when transliterated. The only exceptions are the contractions of 'su' in words. Like Tsutomu isn't usually Su To Mu, but more like Stomu when said. But saying Su To Mu isn't necessarily wrong either. Asuka: Aska not Asooka, etc. It's like the easiest oddity in any language to learn and understand.

posts.sub: Is there a technical name for this trope?
posts.com:
Peak horror is an irreversible transformation of one of the characters. And then another character contemplates what, if anything, is left of the original's humanity. Sometimes resulting in a mercy kill.
The Fly is a good example but it doesn't have to involve body horror.
One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is another.
What DOESN'T count are all those sci-fi Star Trek plots where the crew is transformed and magically fixed by the doctor in the end. It must be PERMANENT. Alien doesn't count either because the alien kills the host. Being possessed by some entity like a demon doesn't count either.
Other films like that?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Saw it yesterday. The visuals are bloody fantastic on the imax screen. The movie is a good middle chapter, but it has that weird feeling where the climax feels like it's the midsection of a longer movie. But since this is a franchise now, I guess all the other films except the 5th one will also have this "incomplete" feeling. The first one felt like a standalone film with 3 acts. This movie has no 3rd act. I still liked it as much as the first one, the effects are worth it and the visual presentation of the film is better than anything else out there. If this were done under a different director and team, it would not come off as this good. Also, I like the new Navi characters. The disappointment that I had with the film was Quaritch and the other human characters. Somehow they're even more cliche and cringe in this one than the first, which I expected Cameron to improve on in this film but he didn't. The standout theme of the film is the whole Sully family thing and the spiritual aspects of Pandora and Navi culture. You want to know what makes this different from Dances with Wolves and Last Samurai? Featherheads and Nips exists, but blue ayyliums don't, so they have a lot more creative freedom in expressing the artistic vision with this movie. The franchise has earned its right to exist. I feel like we can only judge it accurately after its ended. Good shit though. I will watch the 3rd one when it comes out.

the comedy is still better than any comedy manga i've read since though, so it's worth it for the chapters where there isn't a match
